Hi <@U33SVCQN5>, can you elaborate on what Singularity triggered? an insmod of the kernel module ext3?
<@U115P26TB> I guess so, I will confirm when the system admin is back
Well... Singularity images have within it an ext3 file system to which it needs to mount.
<@U115P26TB>  I see. /home is nfs, /work and /project is lustre here at LSU. Here our admins are quite conservative, afraid of breaking production system.  Anything seems a bit abnormal is an alarm.

That is understandable. Singularity does the best it can to mitigate any sort of issues, and is designed around the idea of production use cases on production systems. With that said, it still needs to do some things that are a bit over and above the normal allowances for users. If your admins would like to discuss any of these matters, please feel free to offer them a Slack invite, and/or email me at <mailto:gmkurtzer@lbl.gov|gmkurtzer@lbl.gov>.
<@U115P26TB>, will do. The system admin wondered if I have done any damage to the system. I would think once a singularity container exits, it cleans up after itself, such as unmount that ext3 ?
It dosn't have to unmount it, as it exists within it's own mount (CLONE_NEWNS) namespace. It is separate.
When the process exists, the kernel cleans up that namespace, like it never existed.

hey <@U33SVCQN5> I can try to help - you are trying to bind to a directory in the container?
the config file is going to specify what the (administrator) that installed Singularity allows users to do
so the most permissive would be to allow overlayfs
when it comes to binding to the container itself, the administrator via this file can also define directories to be mounted by default
for example home, and tmp, and on some clusters /scratch
if your administrator does those by default, you won't gain anything by trying to re-do them
so then it comes down to what you would want to do in a definition file, versus runtime

a definition file should generally create directories in the container that you want to exist, for example, I have some analysis containers that I know I'll be using on my cluster, and I do mkdir -p /scratch/PI just to do away with the warning message that it doesn't exist in the container
but I think what you are trying to do is more about runtime binds
in which case you would want to do like
`singularity run -B /scratch/data:/data container.img`
that command is basically a request on the level of the user asking the container to bind the host /scratch/data to /data
now, if the administrator has disabled these custom binds, it's a no go
if the point is already bound in the container, usually via a configuration, then it could also be skipped

attachments.title: Singularity Big Announcement | Singularity
attachments.text: Singularity Big Announcement Apr 28, 2017 / Notice to all Singularity users, contributors, and collaboratorsThis is an important announcement from Greg Kurzer, founder and lead developer of Singularity.Singularity continues to gain popularity and traction very quickly. This growth has been extremely demanding on my time and is outpacing my ability to sustain the broad amount of use cases for the rapidly expanding community with me working on it only part time. In order to meet this rapidly expanding growth, I have created a new organization, SingularityWare, LLC, which is dedicated to further developing Singularity, supporting the associated open source community and growing the project. To facilitate this, I have partnered with a company, RStor, Inc.RStor is not only interested in the success of Singularity, as an open source, scientific enabling platform, but they are bringing their own very compelling and much needed cloud based storage/RDM platform to market. A partnership like this (containerized computing coupled with a cloud based storage platform) offers a very exciting and synergistic value to research <http://computing.In|computing.In> addition to continuing my leadership of Singularity (and the new LLC), I will be maintaining my association with Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, as a scientific advisor as well as continuing other efforts I am associated with (e.g. Warewulf and OpenHPC).This means that I now have the resources and ability to both offer support for Singularity and hire key developers, and I would like to invite interested people to send me your resume! I am looking to hire both part time and full time staff engineers as well as University collaborations to fund interns, graduates and postdocs for Singularity development and relevant involvement.Aside from additional resources, dedication, attention, and growth, the overall direction of the project will remain the same.If you have any questions, comments or want to be part of this exciting new endeavor, please feel free to contact me directly.Thank you! Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Site last generated: Apr 28, 2017

text: you just need to change '%setup' to '%post'
setup is stuff that happens from host to container but not in the actual container making
for example if I wanted to copy files from my host image to the container I could have access to the host from set up, although with singularity 2.3 you don't even need that anymore :)
Ah, gotcha, silly mistake!
Thank you!!

you might need to install PIP too, I'm not sure that python or ubuntu comes with it. I would apt-get update first, then install python and wget, then wget the get_pip.py script and run with python, then you should be good to go!

heyo! If you don't want your container to have the local PATH you can run with `--cleanenv`
if you want to add files to the container, with development branch you can list them like /file/host /container/path under `%files`
you can also define env vars under `%environment`
<https://github.com/singularityware/singularityware.github.io/blob/docs/2.3/pages/docs/user-docs/docs-environment-metadata.md>

text: Ah brill
Although I'm using 2.2.1 because that's what is currently installed on the cluster - would that make a difference?
haha yes, these things don't exist in 2.2.1 :slightly_smiling_face:
for 2.2.1 if you want to add files, you can do that by copying in `%setup` to `$SINGULARITY_ROOTFS`

and for environment it's a bit of a hack as well, in `%post` you want to write environment variables to `/environment` but be careful to write a newline first so you don't break what comes there first
but you can still use the development on your local machine (with the new stuffs) and the on the cluster run the image with the older one
you can try `--contain` or `-c` to better isolate the container, but then you might need to add things back in like mounts lol. I haven't use the old one in a long time :stuck_out_tongue:

hey <@U33SVCQN5> ! Okay, for 1) the warning messages about the non existent bind points are because they are set up to be bound automatically in the config, but not found in the container. If you create them with bootstrap (eg in `%post` have mkdir -p /work && mkdir -p /project` that should be resolved.
It sounds like the paths aren't in the container, and they aren't being generated automatically, so I would next try creating them first in the container, then running

if you have overlay fs enabled but this still isn't working, it suggests that your host system does not support it, in which case you can just give instruction to your users to create those directories with their containers

text: <@U245DTC59> Let's see if I understand correctly. 1st, if I bootstrap an image by myself by adding "mkdir /work or /project" in the .def, then the container would have access to those two dir? Also, for the system here, -bind option not work at all?
given that overlayfs works on the host and is enabled, when you have a directory specified to be mounted in the config, or the user asks via the --bind command, it will be mounted.

given overlayfs doesn't work on the host or it works and isn't enabled, then the config can still specify to have directories mounted, but if they don't exist in the container, they won't be created and mounted (I think this is your situation)
given overlayfs doesn't work but the config allows user mounts, if there is a directory on the host that does exist in the container, it should bind ok

so to answer your question directly to 1) yes, using mkdir for those folders would (I think) have them bound. And 2) --bind would work given paths that exist in both and that it's allowed in the config
<@U245DTC59> thanks, I will test it on the system.  I know I can overwrite an image by adding mkdir, that works

oh this would be great! I think there are a couple of options for going about this

if you want a file maintained with <http://singularityware.github.io|singularityware.github.io> repo, then we can add cut and paste functionality to the repo. There is a jekyll include tag (like {% include links.html %} that would let you include some snippet served with the repo, and the include tag could be done to automatically make it "cut and pastable"

if you want a separate code thing to live with singularityware, but be served as a gist or github repo, then we could have another similar include to link to that, so the user would be taken to github, etc.
You could also build and serve the container via a link with Singularity Hub

attachments.title: Getting Started with Bootstrap | Singularity
attachments.text: Getting Started with Bootstrap Previous Next Bootstrapping a ContainerBootstrapping is the process where we install an operating system and then configure it appropriately for a specified need. To do this we use a bootstrap definition file which is a recipe of how to specifically build the container and explained in detail in the previous section.For the purpose of this example, we will use the portions of the bootstrap definition file above, and assemble it into a complete definition file:# Bootstrap definition example for Centos-7 with the latest Open MPI from GitHub masterBootStrap: yumOSVersion: 7MirrorURL: <http://mirror.centos.org/centos-%{OSVERSION}/%{OSVERSION}/os/$basearch/Include>: yum%setup echo

attachments.title: Singularity: Scientific containers for mobility of compute
attachments.text: Here we present Singularity, software developed to bring containers and reproducibility to scientific computing. Using Singularity containers, developers can work in reproducible environments of their choosing and design, and these complete environments can easily be copied and executed on other platforms. Singularity is an open source initiative that harnesses the expertise of system and software engineers and researchers alike, and integrates seamlessly into common workflows for both of these groups. As its primary use case, Singularity brings mobility of computing to both users and HPC centers, providing a secure means to capture and distribute software and compute environments. This ability to create and deploy reproducible environments across these centers, a previously unmet need, makes Singularity a game changing development for computational science.
attachments.fallback: Singularity: Scientific containers for mobility of compute

hey everyone a little Docker learnings today - we are going to be adding a command (pull) for docker images that performs a create and import simultaneously, and this is most effective if we can estimate the size of the Docker image
we **can** do this, using the manifest from the registry, however it must be schema version 2.0
In testing, I found that some images are returning schema version 1, still, and I looked into why this is the case

it is because if you have a pipeline that is pushing to the hub (instead of having them build for you, for example) if you are using docker 1.9 and earlier, it will default to providing  version 1 manifest
I wrote up the issue here for one of our users if you want details: <https://github.com/poldracklab/mriqc/issues/499>

attachments.title: [something to look into] Update Docker to 1.10 to update manifest version to 2 路 Issue #499 路 poldracklab/mriqc

Just to let you know: my lab (UCSD Yeo Lab) has just released a new Singularity based bio-infomatics pipeline !

text:
A question on the combination of `--contain` and `--nv`: Are we supposed to not see any gpus when we combine these two options?
```user@laptop:~$ singularity shell --nv --contain ./ubuntu.img 
Singularity: Invoking an interactive shell within container...

Singularity ubuntu.img:~> ls /dev/ | grep nvid
Singularity ubuntu.img:~> ```
<@U5FFKV6M6> this is due to `--contain`
remove it and that should work

<@U4BKCNE9K> I know that leaving out `--contain` makes it work again; I just wanted to check whether that's expected behaviour when specifying `--nv` since the latter implies I'm going to want to do some gpu stuff.
Yep, that's normal.
give me 2mn and I ll explain why
Take your time :slightly_smiling_face:

```
    -c/--contain        This option disables the automatic sharing of writable
                        filesystems on your host (e.g. $HOME and /tmp).
```
I think this help is not enough
Indeed, IMHO, it also abstracts everything which is specific on your host
For example, devices
and perhaps env variables

```
    -c/--contain        This option disables the automatic sharing of writable
                        filesystems on your host (e.g. $HOME and /tmp).
    -C/--containall     Contain not only file systems, but also PID and IPC
    -e/--cleanenv       Clean environment before running container
```
Ok. So, it's `--cleanenv` for env variables

And as mentionned above with `--containall` :
```
Contain not only file systems, but also PID and IPC
```
So with `--contain` the container should contain a new whole filesystem. Including _/dev_ or _/proc_ ....
Doc is not very clear on that point
That does make sense, yes.
Do you know whether there's a less extensive `--contain` alternative, which only disables the automatic binding of folders?
You should be able to edit `singularity.conf`

```
# MOUNT HOME: [BOOL]
# DEFAULT: yes
...
```

Where I also just found a bit of explanation on `--contain`:
```# MOUNT DEV: [yes/no/minimal]
# DEFAULT: yes
# Should we automatically bind mount /dev within the container? If 'minimal'
# is chosen, then only 'null', 'zero', 'random', 'urandom', and 'shm' will
# be included (the same effect as the --contain options)```
I'll look into that, thanks.
<@U4BKCNE9K> Good points regarding the help outputs, will you help fix up the wording in the development branch?
Hi <@U115P26TB>. If you want :smiley:
Hiya, yes please :slightly_smiling_face:

Hello , we are preparing to release a second pipeline based on Singularity+CWL. I am running into an issue because in UBUNTU14.04 , python multiprocessing needs the OS to create temporary files in /run/shm and /run/lock.
This issue seems to be related  to the one discussed here : <https://groups.google.com/a/lbl.gov/forum/#!searchin/singularity/multiprocessing/singularity/71MhNumuMbs/H6SOkXGGCAAJ>
The most likely scenario is going to be mac users , installing Singularity according to the instructions here: <http://singularity.lbl.gov/install-mac> This results in a Ubuntu14.04 OS in the vagrant VM .That particular OS is the result of this line : vagrant init ubuntu/trusty64
The solution described in the google doc discussion was to add a line : "bind path = /run" to the /usr/loacal/etc/singularity/singularity.conf file
QUESTION: would it be feasble to add that line to the default singularity.conf file for the 2.3 singularity release ?
If not, would it be OK to change the vagrant installation instruction , so that ubuntu16.04 is used instead of 14.04 ?
Thank you!

text: How does a multiple import to the same image work then? Wouldn't the 2nd clobber the 1st?
yep
but that doesn't mean that people won't do it
Or does some docker repo's act more like stand alone layers/overlays?
does some... do some... whatever
docker is all about layers, like cakes... the majority are read only and there is one write layer on top
one line in a Dockerfile --> one layer
that's why users are encouraged to put as many things in one line as possible, to reduce number of layers I think
but that's not a good approach for singularity, because we want to have entire images

Right... but as seen in Singularity, it's not exactly the pieces... so, for the most part, if you do multiple images, unless specially crafted repos, it's going to blow away what was there previously and you will be left with the last import used yes? Unless there's some docker repos that act as a piece and not the whole...
right
Say like (for example):  <docker://tensorflow/tensorflow:binary>   ... so it would be only the tensorflow piece, and not the OS
the weird decisions for how/what to import are up to the user, I just think it's important that we document all actions
I can see the reason for having the multiple... but to me in how things are actually implemented one import is going to override the previous
yes, this is true
regardless of what gets written / overwritten, we still need to reflect that the user did an import twice
given that we have provided functionality to do import, more than once, on the same image, we also need to provide documentation of those actions
but it's a fine line because I agree we shouldn't advocate
I suppose it's like giving a toddler paint to play with, letting him do whatever, and just making sure it's non toxic :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Yeah... I mean, if it gets extended to where you can setup your own repo for importing images...
that's probably all weird and wrong, but you could come back to that later and see that the user first imported an OS, and then some data to it
what do you mean by that?
You could make targets that could easily fit the multiple import model
the stupidest implementation I can think of is having a container label that specifies some other kind of container label it is "allowed" to import
for example, I might make a base that EXPECTS data to be at /data then a bunch of other .tar.gz with different types of that data

Example would be:
singularity create blah.img 
singularity import blah.img <docker://ubuntu:latest> 
singularity import blah.img <localrepo://apps/R>
singularity import blah.img <localrepo://apps/SomeAppHere>
then I'd just do a check against the required data against the user's wanting to import data, and if it matches, I'd allow the import. If not, I'd say "sorry, don't dump that nonsense in me!"

that above looks more like a local registry for singularity hub, which I am just starting to develop, but it's different than a general import of something that can come from any uri (docker, shub, file)
speaking of, tell me what you would want this localrepo:// to look/work like?
because it could just be a local path, without the localrepo://
so there must be something special about localrepo:// that needs to be parsed/understood
Well, I was just assuming the same layout as shub, docker, etc... just you could define where localrepo pointed to host your own
shub mostly
okay, that will fit nicely under a local registry I think :slightly_smiling_face:
I want to talk more (and think more) about what a "data" or "not the entire thing" import would look like
I can see multiple imports working in that context without destroying what was previously there, since they're more like "layers" in the docker since... just added after the fact

the biggest challenge right now I think is maintaining the model of "this is the full image" but then having an ability to customize just a piece of it (without moving into a model that looks more like docker with layers)
I think if containers are defining about what they can import and where, and then the entire image is maintained, we could have something cool like that :slightly_smiling_face:
As long as there's an override, I wouldn't care. If I want to force something let me. :)
like the little nginx server of containers I made a few months ago, I just defined the different url params as labels, and then the server understood how to serve the container
lol it's still there... <http://35.185.192.61/>
shirksaway...
but that's what is exciting about having a simple thing like labels, and then exposing them easily
it means that any person/third party can have rules regarding how a container connects to his/her application
and then tell users that use their application to just add those labels, and whatever other criteria are needed, and then it works!
and it doesn't even have to be a singularity specified proper thing, the person might tell the user to export a label like `BIOCONTAINER_BASE`, `BIOCONTAINER_DATA`, etc.

text: that's good, but ideally it should execute only one download and put all the following concurrent request for the same image
the case you are talking about is when the image isn't in the cache, and it's asked for multiple times at the same time, within the time it takes to download
once it is downlaoded, it won't be downloaded again
but yes, if there is not the complete file, the others will start their temporary downloads, and then cut when they see a finished one.
what you are suggesting would have the other downloads see a temporary (not finished) download and trust that it would finish
if it fails, or doesn't, then you get stuck
I think it's better to have a few extra s-image.tmp13434 files than to get stuck
> if it fails, or doesn't, then you get stuck
but definitely if you have a good idea for an implementation it would be great to see!
well no, if it fails it would start a new one
I see like a caching mechanism
but how does a second process that sees simage.tmp123 know if it's still going,or failed?
it is done in the cache, at $HOME/.singularity/shub
if there's a local copy it get it otherwise start a new download, all the other requests are just stopped waiting for the running download
unless the user asks for different location
if there is a local copy in the cache it would be used
I don't see how to implement just stopping all other requests given that there could be a shared cache between many users potentially, and all running different processes
I think down the line we could optimize this, but I don't see how it is severely broken now
I will check again the Singularity cache mechanism but it doesn't look to work in this way
but I really like some of your ideas for the local registry - my plan so far is to organize it similarity from shub but have it be a filesystem

attachments.text: Singularity 2.3 Release May 31, 2017 / We have some egg-citing news! Its the release of Singularity 2.3!For the full release announcement and downloads, please see the release on Github.There are a massive number of fixes, updates, optimizations and awesomeness contained within this release, and here are the major ones, in a nutshell: Lots of backend library changes to accommodate a more flexible API Restructured Python backend Updated bootstrap backend to make it much more reliable Direct support for Singularity-Hub Ability to run additional commands without root privileges (e.g. create, import, copy, export, etc..). Added ability to pull images from Singularity Hub and Docker Containers now have labels, and are inspectableWe are excited about the release, and grateful to the community and all contributors. Have fun, egglings! Please report any additional bugs as issues.Thank you! Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Site last generated: Jun 1, 2017

attachments.title: Install on Linux | Singularity
attachments.text: Install on Linux Installation from SourceYou can try the following two options:Option 1: Download latest stable releaseYou can always download the latest tarball release from GithubFor example, here is how to download version 2.2.1 and install:VERSION=2.2.1wget <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/releases/download/$VERSION/singularity-$VERSION.tar.gztar> xvf singularity-$VERSION.tar.gzcd singularity-$VERSION./configure --prefix=/usr/localmakesudo make installOption 2: Download the latest development codeTo download the most recent development code, you should use Git and do the following:git clone <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity.gitcd> singularity./autogen.sh./configure --prefix=/usr/localmakesudo make installnote: The make install is required to be run as root to get a properly installed Singularity implementation. If you do not run it as root, you will only be able to launch Singularity as root due to permission limitations.Show Video Tutorial UpdatingTo update your Singularity version, you might want to first delete the executables for the old version:sudo rm -rf /usr/local/libexec/singularityAnd then install using one of the methods above.Build an RPM from sourceLike the above, you can build an RPM of Singularity so it can be more easily managed, upgraded and removed. From the base Singularity source directory do the following:./autogen.sh./configuremake distrpmbuild -ta singularity-*.tar.gzsudo yum install ~/rpmbuild/RPMS/*/singularity-[0-9]*.rpmNote: if you want to have the RPM install the files to an alternative location, you should define the environment variable PREFIX to suit your needs, and use the following command to build:PREFIX=/opt/singularityrpmbuild -ta --define=

And what us the difference between these 2 builders ? sorry if I missed an explanation somewhere in the documentation....
yes, those are the two!
the builders are exactly the same, minus the size of the disk
most images are ok with 50GB
so that is default. But given some extreme case, we provide a 100GB
they are images that are on Google Cloud
and deployed programatically on demand for each build

and they know how to receive the build from singularity hub, build once to get size, build a second time "for real," and then collect a bunch of metrics/metadata, upload to storage, and then send a signal back to singularity hub to both tell the user, tell shub where the files are on storage, and then shut down the instance

so the builder itself just has a start up script with two calls - the first runs the entire build, and then second is called "finish_build" and as soon as you run it, it's like the builder kills itself

attachments.title: Install on Linux | Singularity
attachments.text: Install on Linux Installation from SourceYou can try the following two options:Option 1: Download latest stable releaseYou can always download the latest tarball release from GithubFor example, here is how to download version 2.3 and install:VERSION=2.3wget <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/releases/download/$VERSION/singularity-$VERSION.tar.gztar> xvf singularity-$VERSION.tar.gzcd singularity-$VERSION./configure --prefix=/usr/localmakesudo make installOption 2: Download the latest development codeTo download the most recent development code, you should use Git and do the following:git clone <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity.gitcd> singularity./autogen.sh./configure --prefix=/usr/localmakesudo make installnote: The make install is required to be run as root to get a properly installed Singularity implementation. If you do not run it as root, you will only be able to launch Singularity as root due to permission limitations.Show Video Tutorial UpdatingTo update your Singularity version, you might want to first delete the executables for the old version:sudo rm -rf /usr/local/libexec/singularityAnd then install using one of the methods above.Debian/Ubuntu PackageSingularity is available on Debian (and Ubuntu) systems starting with Debian stretch and the Ubuntu 16.10 yakkety releases. The package is called singularity-container. For recent releases of singularity and backports for older Debian and Ubuntu releases, we recommend that you use the NeuroDebian repository.Testing first with DockerIf you want a quick preview of the NeuroDebian mirror, you can do this most easily with the NeuroDebian Docker image (and if you dont, skip to the next section). Obviously you should have Docker installed before you do this.First we run the neurodebian Docker image:$ docker run -it --rm neurodebianThen we update the cache (very quietly), and look at the singularity-container policy provided:$ apt-get update -qqq$ apt-cache policy singularity-containersingularity-container: Installed: (none) Candidate: 2.3-1~nd80+1 Version table: 2.3-1~nd80+1 0 500 <http://neuro.debian.net/debian/> jessie/main amd64 PackagesYou can continue worker in Docker, or go back to your host and install Singularity.Adding the Mirror and InstallingYou should first enable the NeuroDebian repository following instructions on the NeuroDebian site. This means using the dropdown menus to find the correct mirror for your operating system and location. For example, after selecting Ubuntu 16.04 and selecting a mirror in CA, I am instructed to add these lists:sudo wget -O- <http://neuro.debian.net/lists/xenial.us-ca.full> | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/neurodebian.sources.listsudo apt-key adv --recv-keys --keyserver <hkp://pool.sks-keyservers.net:80> 0xA5D32F012649A5A9and then updatesudo apt-get updatethen singularity can be installed as follows:sudo apt-get install -y singularity-containerDuring the above, if you have a previously installed configuration, you might be asked if you want to define a custom configuration/init, or just use the default provided by the package, eg:Configuration file '/etc/singularity/init' ==> File on system created by you or by a script. ==> File also in package provided by package maintainer. What would you like to do about it ? Your options are: Y or I : install the package maintainer's version N or O : keep your currently-installed version D : show the differences between the versions Z : start a shell to examine the situation The default action is to keep your current version.*** init (Y/I/N/O/D/Z) [default=N] ? YConfiguration file '/etc/singularity/singularity.conf' ==> File on system created by you or by a script. ==> File also in package provided by package maintainer. What would you like to do about it ? Your options are: Y or I : install the package maintainer's version N or O : keep your currently-installed version D : show the differences between the versions Z : start a shell to examine the situation The default action is to keep your current version.*** singularity.conf (Y/I/N/O/D/Z) [default=N] ? YAnd for a user, its probably well suited to use the defaults. For a cluster admin, we recommend that you read the admin docs to get a better understanding of the configuration file options available to you. Remember that you can always tweak the files at /etc/singularity/singularity.conf and /etc/singularity/init if you want to make changes.After this install, you should confirm that 2.3-dist is the version installed:$ singularity --version 2.3-distNote that if you dont add the NeuroDebian lists, the version provided will be old (e.g., 2.2.1). If you need a backport build of the recent release of Singularity on those or older releases of Debian and Ubuntu, you can see all the various builds and other information here.Build an RPM from sourceLike the above, you can build an RPM of Singularity so it can be more easily managed, upgraded and removed. From the base Singularity source directory do the following:./autogen.sh./configuremake distrpmbuild -ta singularity-*.tar.gzsudo yum install ~/rpmbuild/RPMS/*/singularity-[0-9]*.rpmNote: if you want to have the RPM install the files to an alternative location, you should define the environment variable PREFIX to suit your needs, and use the following command to build:PREFIX=/opt/singularityrpmbuild -ta --define=

Hi! i have singularity 2.3 installed but "singularity help" and singularity TAB for auto completion do not include inspect. I suspect I have a bash_completion.d/singularity file from an old installation somewhere that is interfering. I have a file in /usr/local/etc/bash_completion.d/singularity and it looks like the one in the 2.3 version on github. I found another one here: /etc//bash_completion.d/singularity which was an old version. I removed it. But I still don't see inspect in help and bash completion. Would there be another location I should look at ? Thanks
Hi, thanks for invite !
Heya <@U5RJ04A4F>, welcome!

<@U247AF8DP> Singularity does not assume it knows the best place to put the bash_completion.d, and it is a hard thing to 'assume' generally. So, you should copy or link the one in `/usr/local/etc/bash_completion.d/singularity` and move it to the system version at `/etc/bash_completion.d/`.
`ln -s /usr/local/etc/bash_completion.d/singularity /etc/bash_completion.d/singularity`
`source /etc/bash_completion.d/singularity`
would do it

> i just do service nginx start

Don't know the distro you're running, but the RHEL variants when you do that, it calls systemctl unless you hack the /etc/init.d/functions file to make it do what you want

<@U115P26TB> That works, bash tab completion is working, thanks! Now what about the usage information: what files should I move to where so I get the correct help when doing `singularity --help` ? thanks

Hiya <@U4XPXU6K0>. The way the overlay looks from something like a `df` or `mount` is a bit misleading, but that is the writable overlayFS sitting ontop of a non-writable container.

You can theoretically setup a way to SSH into a running singularity image on a remote host... but, there isn't a good way. The basic workflow as it stands is mpiexec calls the image, and the image is stand alone. It doesn't try to make its own MPI calls... since then you're trying to setup a MPI session that an image has no easy way of connecting to. <@U115P26TB> had some thoughts on how to make it feasible... but IIRC, that was in the 0.x days :/

But I don't really see how that would work because you can't call `singularity exec` within the container.  Even if you have singularity installed.  That is unless you are root, because how is the SUID process going to work?

Looking at etc/init in the singularity source it looks like SINGULARITYENV_PATH might simply be overwritten and non-usable
SINGULARITYENV_PATH="/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin"
Why, oh why?
I can confirm it since setting SINGULARITYENV_PATH in my environment before running singularity shell shows that only the above hardcoded value is present.

I just changed etc/singularity/init to 
if [[ "x${SINGULARITYENV_PATH}" == "x" ]]; then
           SINGULARITYENV_PATH="/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin"
fi
and now SINGULARITYENV_PATH works inside the container!
I'll submit a pull request to fix this bug  in 2.3
<https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/pull/755> submitted

Hi,
Is there any reproducibility expert around ?
I am trying to determine what could change a result within a container from a host to another.
or on the same host

From now, my list is the following:
  - the kernel version
  - the way you compile/recompile your program if it's needed
  - libraries used and their versions
  - processor type (Intel, AMD), arch (32/64) and its features (SSE, AVX...).
  - locales, encoding
  - local time
  - some devices, and specific character devides (eg: /dev/urandom)
  - floating point precision
  - endianness.


Any other ideas ?
random number used in the code (cf monte carlo, crypto,...) see also Debian's Reproducible Builds effort at <https://wiki.debian.org/ReproducibleBuilds>

I feel dumb for not knowing this :confused: , but how do I propagate some variables from my environment into the container when I execute `shell` or `exec`?
I basically want my container to know where it is (on the hostsystem).  Is this possible?
<@U115P26TB> sure

<@U2MT7BF0V> 

Container /singularity contains;
printf This message is being printed from the container: MYVAR=${MYVAR}\n

You can either run it this way;

MYVAR=eric    /tmp/centos7-ompi-master.img

or export the variable before as in;

[singular@singular2 ~]$ export MYVAR=eric_exported
[singular@singular2 ~]$ /tmp/centos7-ompi-master.img
This message is being printed from the container: MYVAR=eric_exported
so the user env simple moved into the image?
explicitly exported, or command prefixed vars  persist in child processes
ok

attachments.title: The Bootstrap Definition | Singularity
attachments.text: The Bootstrap Definition The process of bootstrapping a Singularity container is equivalent to describing a recipe for the container creation. There are several recipe formats that Singularity supports, but only the primary format of version 2.3 will be documented here. If you want a general overview with examples, see Bootstrapping an Image. The detailed options for each of the header and sections are provided here.The header fields:Bootstrap:The Bootstrap: keyword identifies the Singularity module that will be used for building the core components of the operating system. There are several supported modules at the time of this writing:yumThe YUM bootstrap module uses YUM on the host system to bootstrap the core operating system that exists within the container. This module is applicable for bootstrapping distributions like Red Hat, Centos, and Scientific Linux. When using the yum bootstrap module, several other keywords may also be necessary to define: MirrorURL: This is the location where the packages will be downloaded from. When bootstrapping different RHEL/YUM compatible distributions of Linux, this will define which variant will be used (e.g. the only difference in bootstrapping Centos from Scientific Linux is this line. OSVersion: When using the yum bootstrap module, this keyword is conditional and required only if you have specified a %{OSVERSION} variable name in the MirrorURL keyword. If the MirrorURL definition does not have the %{OSVERSION} variable, OSVersion can be omitted from the header field. Include: By default the core operating system is an extremely minimal base, which may or may not include the means to even install additional packages. The Include keyword should define any additional packages which should be used and installed as part of the core operating system bootstrap. The best practice is to keep this keyword usage as minimal as possible such that you can then use the %inside scriptlet (explained shortly) to do additional installations. One common package you may want to include here is yum itself.Warning, there is a major limitation with using YUM to bootstrap a container and that is the RPM database that exists within the container will be created using the RPM library and Berkeley DB implementation that exists on the host system. If the RPM implementation inside the container is not compatible with the RPM database that was used to create the container, once the container has been created RPM and YUM commands inside the container may fail. This issue can be easily demonstrated by bootstrapping an older RHEL compatible image by a newer one (e.g. bootstrap a Centos 5 or 6 container from a Centos 7 host).debootstrapThe Debian bootstrap module is a tool which is used specifically for bootstrapping distributions which utilize the .deb package format and apt-get repositories. This module will bootstrap any of the Debian and Ubuntu based distributions. When using the debootstrap module, the following keywords must also be defined: MirrorURL: This is the location where the packages will be downloaded from. When bootstrapping different Debian based distributions of Linux, this will define which varient will be used (e.g. specifying a different URL can be the difference between Debian or Ubuntu). OSVersion: This keyword must be defined as the alpha-character string associated with the version of the distribution you wish to use. For example, trusty or stable. Include: As with the yum module, the Include keyword will install additional packages into the core operating system and the best practice is to supply only the bare essentials such that the %inside scriptlet has what it needs to properly completely the bootstrap.archThe Arch Linux bootstrap module does not name any additional keywords at this time. By defining the arch module, you have essentially given all of the information necessary for that particular bootstrap module to build a core operating system.dockerThe Docker bootstrap module will create a core operating system image based on an image hosted on a particular Docker Registry server. By default it will use the primary Docker Library, but that can be overridden. When using the docker module, several other keywords may also be defined: From: This keyword defines the string of the registry name used for this image in the format [name]:[version]. Several examples are: ubuntu:latest, centos:6, alpine:latest, or debian (if the version tag is ommitted, :latest is automatically used). IncludeCmd: This keyword tells Singularity to utilize the Docker defined Cmd as the %runscript (defined below), if the Cmd is defined. Registry: If the registry you wish to download the image from is not from the main Docker Library, you can define it here. Token: Sometimes the Docker API (depending on version?) requires an authorization token which is generated on the fly. Toggle this with a yes or no here.Bootstrap sections:Once the Bootstrap module has completed, the sections are identified and utilized if present. The following sections are supported in the bootstrap definition, and integrated during the bootstrap process:%setupThis section blob is a Bourne shell scriptlet which will be executed on the host outside the container during bootstrap. The path to the container is accessible from within the running scriptlet environment via the variable $SINGULARITY_ROOTFS. For example, consider the following scriptlet:%setup echo

attachments.title: Singularity on HPC | Singularity
attachments.text: Singularity on HPC One of the architecturally defined features in Singularity is that it can execute containers like they are native programs or scripts on a host computer. As a result, integration with schedulers is simple and runs exactly as you would expect. All standard input, output, error, pipes, IPC, and other communication pathways that locally running programs employ are synchronized with the applications running locally within the container.Additionally, because Singularity is not emulating a full hardware level virtualization paradigm, there is no need to separate out any sandboxed networks or file systems because there is no concept of user-escalation within a container. Users can run Singularity containers just as they run any other program on the HPC resource.WorkflowsWe are in the process of developing Singularity Hub, which will allow for generation of workflows using Singularity containers in an online interface, and easy deployment on standard research clusters (e.g., SLURM, SGE). Currently, the Singularity core software is installed on the following research clusters, meaning you can run Singularity containers as part of your jobs: The Sherlock cluster at Stanford University SDSC Comet and Gordon (XSEDE) MASSIVE M1 M2 and M3 (Monash University and Australian National Merit Allocation Scheme)Integration with MPIAnother result of the Singularity architecture is the ability to properly integrate with the Message Passing Interface (MPI). Work has already been done for out of the box compatibility with Open MPI (both in Open MPI v2.1.x as well as part of Singularity). The Open MPI/Singularity workflow works as follows: mpirun is called by the resource manager or the user directly from a shell Open MPI then calls the process management daemon (ORTED) The ORTED process launches the Singularity container requested by the mpirun command Singularity builds the container and namespace environment Singularity then launches the MPI application within the container The MPI application launches and loads the Open MPI libraries The Open MPI libraries connect back to the ORTED process via the Process Management Interface (PMI) At this point the processes within the container run as they would normally directly on the host.This entire process happens behind the scenes, and from the users perspective running via MPI is as simple as just calling mpirun on the host as they would normally.Below are example snippets of building and installing OpenMPI into a container and then running an example MPI program through Singularity.Tutorials Using Host libraries: GPU drivers and OpenMPI BTLsMPI Development ExampleWhat are supported Open MPI Version(s)?To achieve proper containerized Open MPI support, you should use Open MPI version 2.1. There are however three caveats: Open MPI 1.10.x may work but we expect you will need exactly matching version of PMI and Open MPI on both host and container (the 2.1 series should relax this requirement) Open MPI 2.1.0 has a bug affecting compilation of libraries for some interfaces (particularly Mellanox interfaces using libmxm are known to fail). If your in this situation you should usethe master branch of Open MPI rather than the release. Using Open MPI 2.1 does not magically allow your container to connect to networking fabric libraries in the host. If your cluster has, for example, an infiniband network you still need to install OFED libraries into the container. Alternatively you could bind mount both Open MPI and networking libraries into the container, but this could run afoul of glib compatibility issues (its generally OK if the container glibc is more recent than the host, but not the other way around)Code Example using Open MPI 2.1.0 Stable$ # Include the appropriate development tools into the container (notice we are calling$ # singularity as root and the container is writeable)$ sudo singularity exec -w /tmp/Centos-7.img yum groupinstall

I'm having trouble understanding how filesystems are working in some cases. 
This I understand:
`singularity exec -w -B /home container.img make install`
This to me says that /home is bind mounted, and to execute `make install` in the current directory. if the current directory is visible in the container then all is good.
What I don't understand is this:
`singularity exec container.img ./configure --prefix=/whatever`
Here I haven't told singularity to mount `/home`
so shouldn't the command fail?
Yet it seems that such commands work as long as you aren't trying to write to a filepath within the container.

<@U5T7HTNCR> unless you or you admin have altered it, the `singularity.conf` file determines what directories should be bind mounted by default within the container.  `/home/$USER` is one of those.  So are things like `/tmp`, `/dev`, `/proc`

so no voodoo here

Note that your first example also says something a bit different:

It says that `/home` outside the container is bind mounted to `/home` inside the container and to execute `make install` within your `/home/$USER` directory (because that is where you will start unless you use the `--pwd` option).

If that's true then the command should fail because the source directory (where `make install` would work) is in a subdirectory of `/home/$USER`. It seems like `--pwd` is being specified for me by default as well..
otherwise `make install` would say something like 'can't find Makefile'

attachments.title: Singularity on HPC | Singularity
attachments.text: Singularity on HPC One of the architecturally defined features in Singularity is that it can execute containers like they are native programs or scripts on a host computer. As a result, integration with schedulers is simple and runs exactly as you would expect. All standard input, output, error, pipes, IPC, and other communication pathways that locally running programs employ are synchronized with the applications running locally within the container.Additionally, because Singularity is not emulating a full hardware level virtualization paradigm, there is no need to separate out any sandboxed networks or file systems because there is no concept of user-escalation within a container. Users can run Singularity containers just as they run any other program on the HPC resource.WorkflowsWe are in the process of developing Singularity Hub, which will allow for generation of workflows using Singularity containers in an online interface, and easy deployment on standard research clusters (e.g., SLURM, SGE). Currently, the Singularity core software is installed on the following research clusters, meaning you can run Singularity containers as part of your jobs: The Sherlock cluster at Stanford University SDSC Comet and Gordon (XSEDE) MASSIVE M1 M2 and M3 (Monash University and Australian National Merit Allocation Scheme)Integration with MPIAnother result of the Singularity architecture is the ability to properly integrate with the Message Passing Interface (MPI). Work has already been done for out of the box compatibility with Open MPI (both in Open MPI v2.1.x as well as part of Singularity). The Open MPI/Singularity workflow works as follows: mpirun is called by the resource manager or the user directly from a shell Open MPI then calls the process management daemon (ORTED) The ORTED process launches the Singularity container requested by the mpirun command Singularity builds the container and namespace environment Singularity then launches the MPI application within the container The MPI application launches and loads the Open MPI libraries The Open MPI libraries connect back to the ORTED process via the Process Management Interface (PMI) At this point the processes within the container run as they would normally directly on the host.This entire process happens behind the scenes, and from the users perspective running via MPI is as simple as just calling mpirun on the host as they would normally.Below are example snippets of building and installing OpenMPI into a container and then running an example MPI program through Singularity.Tutorials Using Host libraries: GPU drivers and OpenMPI BTLsMPI Development ExampleWhat are supported Open MPI Version(s)?To achieve proper containerized Open MPI support, you should use Open MPI version 2.1. There are however three caveats: Open MPI 1.10.x may work but we expect you will need exactly matching version of PMI and Open MPI on both host and container (the 2.1 series should relax this requirement) Open MPI 2.1.0 has a bug affecting compilation of libraries for some interfaces (particularly Mellanox interfaces using libmxm are known to fail). If your in this situation you should usethe master branch of Open MPI rather than the release. Using Open MPI 2.1 does not magically allow your container to connect to networking fabric libraries in the host. If your cluster has, for example, an infiniband network you still need to install OFED libraries into the container. Alternatively you could bind mount both Open MPI and networking libraries into the container, but this could run afoul of glib compatibility issues (its generally OK if the container glibc is more recent than the host, but not the other way around)Code Example using Open MPI 2.1.0 Stable$ # Include the appropriate development tools into the container (notice we are calling$ # singularity as root and the container is writeable)$ sudo singularity exec -w /tmp/Centos-7.img yum groupinstall

attachments.title: Create an Image | Singularity
attachments.text: Create an Image A Singularity image, which can be referred to as a container, is a single file that contains a virtual file system. After creating an image you can install an operating system, applications, and save meta-data with it.Whereas Docker assembles images from layers that are stored on your computer (viewed with the docker -ps command), a Singularity image is just one file that can sit on your Desktop, in a folder on your cluster, or anywhere.Having Singularity containers housed within a single image file greatly simplifies management tasks such as sharing, copying, and branching your containers. It also means that standard Linux file system concepts like permissions, ownership, and ACLs apply to the container (e.g. I can give read only access to a colleague, or block access completely with a simple chmod command).Creating a new blank Singularity container imageSingularity will create a default container image of 768MiB using the following command:$ singularity create container.imgInitializing Singularity image subsystemOpening image file: container.imgCreating 768MiB imageBinding image to loopCreating file system within imageImage is done: container.imgHow big is it?$ du -sh container.img 29M container.imgWe can now use ls to list details about the image.$ ls -l container.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 805306400 Apr 15 11:11 container.imgNote the permissions of the image make it executable. Singularity images can be executed directly.Creating an image of a different sizeYou can change the maximum size of an image you create using the --size option. Note that --size is not a global option. It is an option to the create sub-command and must therefore follow it:$ singularity create --size 2048 container2.imgInitializing Singularity image subsystemOpening image file: container2.imgCreating 2048MiB imageBinding image to loopCreating file system within imageImage is done: container2.img$ ls -lh container*.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 2.1G Apr 15 11:34 container2.img-rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 769M Apr 15 11:11 container.imgOverwriting an image with a new oneIf you have already created an image and wish to overwrite it, you can do so with the --force option. This option must also follow the create sub-command.$ singularity create --size 512 --force container2.imgInitializing Singularity image subsystemOpening image file: container2.imgCreating 512MiB imageBinding image to loopCreating file system within imageImage is done: container2.img$ ls -lh container*.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 513M Apr 15 11:39 container2.img-rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 769M Apr 15 11:11 container.imgShow Video Tutorial Increasing the size of an existing imageYou can increase the size of an image after it has been instantiated by using the expand Singularity sub-command as follows:$ ls -lh container.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 769M Apr 15 11:11 container.img$ singularity expand container.img Initializing Singularity image subsystemOpening image file: container.imgExpanding image by 768MiBBinding image to loopChecking file systeme2fsck 1.42.13 (17-May-2015)Pass 1: Checking inodes, blocks, and sizesPass 2: Checking directory structurePass 3: Checking directory connectivityPass 4: Checking reference countsPass 5: Checking group summary information/dev/loop0: 11/49152 files (0.0% non-contiguous), 7387/196608 blocksResizing file systemresize2fs 1.42.13 (17-May-2015)Resizing the filesystem on /dev/loop0 to 393216 (4k) blocks.The filesystem on /dev/loop0 is now 393216 (4k) blocks long.Image is done: container.img$ ls -lh container.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 1.6G Apr 15 12:21 container.imgSimilar to the create sub-command, you can override the default size increase (which is 768MiB) by using the --size option.Show Video Tutorial Mounting an imageOnce an image has been created and an OS has been added with the import or bootstrap commands, you can use the shell command to start an interactive shell within the container. But this is not possible when an image does not yet contain a functional OS or shell. For debugging, development, or simply inspecting an image that lacks a functional shell you can use the mount command like so:$ mkdir /tmp/container$ singularity mount container.img /tmp/container/container.img is mounted at: /tmp/container/Spawning a new shell in this namespace, to unmount, exit shellSingularity: \w> dfFilesystem 1K-blocks Used Available Use% Mounted on/dev/loop0 1531760 1172 1451948 1% /tmp/containerSingularity: \w> cd /tmp/containerSingularity: \w> ls -a. .. lost+foundShow Video Tutorial At this point the image just contains a bare file system because we havent used something like the bootstrap or import commands to install an OS.Singularity mounts images in private name-spaces so that the mount is only visible and accessible from within the freshly spawned shell. When you are finished, you can simply exit the shell and the file system will be automatically unmounted.Files can be copied from the image to the host when it is mounted in this way, but they cannot be copied from the host into the image. This is because the image is mounted in read-only mode by default and the mount point is owned by the root user. To copy files into a mounted image, first become root and then mount the image with the --writable option to the mount sub-command.$ sudo -i# singularity mount --writable /home/user/container.img /tmp/containerShow Video Tutorial Copying, sharing, branching, and distributing your imageA primary goal of Singularity is mobility. The single file image format makes mobility easy.Because Singularity images are single files, they are easily copied and managed. You can copy the image to create a branch, share the image and distribute the image as easily as copying any other file you control!If you want an automated solution for building and hosting your image, you can use our container registry Singularity Hub. Singulairty Hub can automatically build bootstrap specification files from a Github repository each time that you push. It provides a simple cloud solution for storing and sharing your image. it will be a comparison of python versions and performance, natively, containery, package, or from source

<@U4BKCNE9K> I think the key to <@U3NE4A4M8> s benchmarks that you are referencing is that the container is mounted as read only.  This allows the kernel to cache the contents and then when python starts opening thousands or 10s of thousands of files, they are all cached instead of being on network storage somewhere.  Does that basically sum it up <@U115P26TB>?

<@U4BKCNE9K> <@U2MT7BF0V> that was my interpretation - the container contents are cached and metadata queries from the perspective of the application in the container (e.g. stat calls on libraries in the python sys.path) become cached data reads from the perspective of the shared NFS file system.
And because singularity container is only one file ? At the opposite, if you have many versions you need to stat/read it again ? It is no more cached. ??

I dont think it has to do with it being a single file vs many.  Because after it is mounted a container is also a lot of files.  I think the key is really that it is *read only*.  Thats what allows it to be cached.
<@U2MT7BF0V> Just for my understanding, do you mean that caching will not happen for read-write data or you mean it will simply be inefficient because of invalidation on write?
I don't know the details at that level. I'm basing my assertion on a convo I had with <@U115P26TB>. I'm sure he could clarify where I cannot.

attachments.fallback: GitHub: Infrastructure for Security (and other) Checks by vsoch 路 Pull Request #789 路 singularityware/singularity

text: you know, level 3 hello world can be very dangerous

one thing I'm not decided on (for which your feedback would be good) is how to act on FAIL tests. Right now the check doesn't do anything but print a status, and I was thinking there could be an option (given appropriate permissions) to fix the image. The issue with this, however, is that it's not captured that it was fixed in metadata or the bootstrap file, so we would need to either require fixes to happen only at bootstrap, and then allow checks after bootstrap (but no fix option, or for a user developing an image, an instruction on how to fix that he/she can add to the bootstrap file
and if it does happen at bootstrap, it's not enough to say that "fix X was performed" we would want to capture the fix command in some more reproducible way.
because the idea of the checks folder is that it should be easy for admins to add custom checks, and people ideally will contribute PRs with various checks they think are important

they don't have to be security, they can be like "does this image have the right version of X and Y and Z? is it web ready? is the OS something specific? are permissions on this thing ok? does it have the folders to run on this cluster? etc"
what I'm hoping is that there could be robust checks that a user is allowed to run, so he/she can make an image, and then choose some check group to run, and get feedback about better practices
thats why the `singularity check ubuntu.img` workflow shouldn't implement a fix (which is more appropriate for bootstrap)
You mean by also using %test in bootstrap ?
it's the same idea, but with a few more options
and no exit on fail, just alert or fix

<@U2WSZL9L2> sorry wasn't around earlier - the bootstrap uses the same cache for docker layers as <@U604H3B2A> mentioned, so if you want to work off grid you could run a "fake" bootstrap to get the layers (or import with sudo) and the layers should be cached at root's home.

I have a general question for folk. If we generally feel okay about dumping layers into an image (.tar.gz) and these layers happen to be an entire OS, would it be weird to dump some similar layers that are just pieces of it? Is that too messy / likely to break things? I like the idea and (I think) if it could be done in an organized fashion (eg, modular things dumping with rules about where they go) it may not be such a nutty idea
my first instinct is that it's a bit messy and not reproducible, but I really want modularity!
<@U2WSZL9L2> maybe you would need to setup a local singularity registry when it will be available. Poke <@U245DTC59> :wink:

Otherwise you could setup a docker registry on your laptop and use it with singularity.
I think it s more neat than using basic files
And could be used on a local network when you will plug your laptop on a network
haha yeah I suppose that could be another use case - but I need time to program! lol
I'm literally hiding in this hotel with my laptop so I can work, heh
:slightly_smiling_face:
but I have to go out at some point to print my boarding pass
preparing to retreat from dinosaur cave...
tiny arms, ready!
:wink:

but <@U4BKCNE9K> and <@U2WSZL9L2> that's a really good idea/use case - there is technically no reason that the same guts for a registry couldn't be used by a single user to manage images, and the only difference would be how that registry / user registry interacts with singularity hub, and builds
it might actually be easier to make that a first goal, and then adopt for clusters, because doing the first will get most of the implementation stuff (views, web sockets, whatever) out of the way
a "local" build would just be another (likely the default) template for the builder
and there would likely be only a tiny number allowed to run at once, heh
<@U68KP7Q07> does it work outside singularity ?
So basically an opportunity to redefine the docker registry URL, or shub one in the config file. Can shub be used to bootstrap? Or just whole images only?
Bootstrap would mean dumping one image onto another... Im not sure we have logic for that yet.
The issue is even worse when building virtual box images with vagrant...even with good bandwidth it takes ages
I guess I can set up local centos repo for that

general question - if you guys were setting up a local registry, where would you want it installed? it meaning storage for images, and then the registry singularity image (and other executables) themselves

the issue comes down to the application's database - it's easy for an institution because they will use "real" databases like postgre /sqlite, that are external to the (sometimes read only) registry image

but for a user, the user shouldn't need to know about databases to set them up. So I have two options. Either make it dockerized and provide postgres for him her, which is something I'm moving away from because I don't want to add that dependency
or use the simple flat file sqlite database, which obviously is just for one person
so I am trying out the second, but then the question is, where to put it? We can't have it live inside the registry image, because then writable must be used every time
we can't really put it in /tmp, because then someone restarts and it goes away
we can't put it in the same install location, because maybe the permissions will get messed up
I was going to put it in the singularity cache, but then there is the weird case of running as root or the user, that's two different locations
so *I think* what makes sense is to have the user install (and have the database) completely somewhere in $HOME, but that doesn't feel like good practice to me
does anyone have suggestions?
from the top of my head, I would have said $HOME
<@U245DTC59> in our local gitlab instance perhaps?
lol, I don't even know what that means
is that a file path?
think like, where on your computer, the registry is software, not just repos
<@U245DTC59> we would like to store it on the shared fs, available without having to talk to a real sql server
maybe could configure to have either/both per-user or cluster-public images
as soon as you have something to share we would be excited to test :slightly_smiling_face:
no this is for a user registry now, hehe
user registry == one person, on your local machine
institution registry == what you are talking about
ok
dude, give me time, I'm like one tiny person
I can assure you I'm working on this constantly
it's not something I'm rushing to get out, it has to be done right
so

but the shared FS is not easily generalizable
<@U245DTC59> no rush, you're doing great. sorry for misunderstanding
our home is on the shared fs, so this could work too
sorry I'm not being clear, this version I'm talking about now is not for a cluster
it's for a personal computer
